text: It's the commission that ruins not hedging for me.  You obviously pay a lot more when you win big/lose big vs win small/lose small.  Maybe if my hedges were really bad value then it would be advantageous to not have them but they're not bad, so they save me more comm than they cost in value.

text: Is there any "stickiness" in racing odds from anyone's experience? I have seen this with cricket especially, the odds sometimes lag the reality on the ground because of the immense volume of mug money. I'm wondering if the same is true of racing. So much money is matched before anyone sees the horse, so that should have some kind of influence on the starting price, even though it doesn't completely reflect the reality on the ground. If this assumption is correct, there is less value in hedging because the odds should be headed further in or out than what the market is currently offering.

elements.text: Is there any "stickiness" in racing odds from anyone's experience? I have seen this with cricket especially, the odds sometimes lag the reality on the ground because of the immense volume of mug money. I'm wondering if the same is true of racing. So much money is matched before anyone sees the horse, so that should have some kind of influence on the starting price, even though it doesn't completely reflect the reality on the ground. If this assumption is correct, there is less value in hedging because the odds should be headed further in or out than what the market is currently offering.

text: Most horse money arrives when/after they're paraded so there isn't much lag if one comes out with 3 legs.   Something like 45-50% comes in in the last 5 mins.   And short time before the off the money dries up and it doesn't take a lot for the SP to be pulled around as people take any perceived value.

elements.text: Most horse money arrives when/after they're paraded so there isn't much lag if one comes out with 3 legs.   Something like 45-50% comes in in the last 5 mins.   And short time before the off the money dries up and it doesn't take a lot for the SP to be pulled around as people take any perceived value.

text: I'm profitable but have a lifetime comm/gross ratio of about 39% so no.  And I'm not at PC2 levels yet. But either way you pay more commission on a days racing with big wins/big losses than with small wins/losses that are making the same overall gross, which can make a marginal edge vanish.  The maths might be different depending on what you pay/what you do/edge size etc but re PC,  I'd rather be paying 40% of something than 10% of nothing at the end of the week so much as I'd love to get an extra point or two by being judicious with my hedging, I can't afford to. I hope I'm wrong but if so I can't see it.

elements.text: I'm profitable but have a lifetime comm/gross ratio of about 39% so no.  And I'm not at PC2 levels yet. But either way you pay more commission on a days racing with big wins/big losses than with small wins/losses that are making the same overall gross, which can make a marginal edge vanish.  The maths might be different depending on what you pay/what you do/edge size etc but re PC,  I'd rather be paying 40% of something than 10% of nothing at the end of the week so much as I'd love to get an extra point or two by being judicious with my hedging, I can't afford to. I hope I'm wrong but if so I can't see it.

text: This is my hesitancy with hedging at BSP. A late swing could turn the hedge into a guaranteed negative outcome even if your opening bet was on the right side of the equation

text: or visa versa? Every bet is just a bet whether you call it a 'hedge' or not, so you'd have to make a continual assessment about the price being value or not, and when the flag drops you'll either have a 'hedge' bet in place or not I guess.  And what you can think by observation can fall apart doing 100s a day so despite the long reply, I don't know :)
